Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Geometric and Topological Analysis on Trajectory Sensing: Collection, Classification and Anonymization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The maturing of mobile devices and systems provide an unprecedented opportunity to collect a large amount of data about real world human motion at all scales. The rich knowledge contained in these data sets can have a huge impact in many fields ranging from transportation to health care, from civil engineering to energy management, from e-commerce to social networking. While the applications are paradigm-transforming, recent studies show that the trajectory data can raise serious privacy concerns in revealing personally sensitive information such as frequently visited locations or social ties. These concerns become the major hurdle in utilizing these data sets. This project systematically studies the issue of anonymizing trajectory data, from the bottom layer of trajectory sensing and data collection, to the middle layer of trajectory representation and anonymity, to the application layer of how the anonymized trajectory data can be used.

By the nature of trajectories as being time stamped sequence of points, in this project novel geometric and topological algorithms that directly work on distributed sensors collecting the trajectories are developed for achieving the objective. Queries to such decentralized sensors are made to ensure no sensitive information is released. The intellectual contribution lies in the following aspects. 1) The topological representation of trajectories, i.e., how trajectories pass around obstacles and landmarks in the domain is adopted. The topological representation is compact and descriptive, introducing novel discrete and combinatorial problems to study. 2) A novel framework is developed for distributed sensors to directly learn, classify and compare the topological types of the target trajectories, using harmonic one-forms and Hodge decomposition from algebraic topology. The new framework can substantially reduce the communication cost within the network, while maintaining the requirement of user privacy from the very beginning of sensing and data collection. 3) A family of anonymization algorithms using different ideas are developed, by altering the way to connect the time-stamped points into trajectories, by adjusting the topological resolution to reach a balance between data anonymity and utility, and by sensing and recording randomized hash data to answer popular trajectory queries. 4) The trajectory data sets are often huge, so algorithms for handling large scale trajectory data sets are developed in both centralized and decentralized settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Technology innovation in wireless communication and mobile devices have enabled the possibility to collect a large number of location and trajectory data. Such location data has serious privacy issues as one can easily infer important and personally sensitive information such as frequently visited locations (often home or work addresses) and social ties from co-appearances of two individuals. In this project we systematically study the problem of sanitization of location and trajectory data, by considering both impossibility results and fundamental limits as well as practical privacy preserving algorithms for useful data mining, aggregation and query.

We first investigate challenges in protecting privacy in location and trajectory data. We have two major discoveries. First, we show that common sense knowledge such as maximum travel speed can be used to develop novel attacks for location inference from co-location appearances, even for users who do not explicitly share location data. Specifically, users who are at the same location at the same time can often be detected by proximity based wireless communication (e.g,m Bluetooth handshaking signals). Such knowledge, together with the maximum travel speed, provide constraints on the distance between these meeting events. Second, we show that social ties from co-appearance patterns can be used to infer socially contagious attributes, even if these attributes are perturbed. 

On the positive side, we developed a number of algorithms for extracting useful statistical aggregates from location data. For example, we show that by using a carefully designed hierarchy, we can implement a perturbation scheme on a planar graph such that range query on shortest paths on the planar graph can be answered achieving logarithmic privacy and utility tradeoff, where perturbations are added to the sensors on the edges of the planar graph. We also show new approximation algorithms for the r-gather problem, where location of mobile users are grouped into square cloaking boxes of r or more users. The cloaking boxes are continuously maintained when the users move, with the size of the boxes to be at most a constant factor of the minimum size possible in every snapshot. We also develop new sampling methods that can help to infer popularly travelled routes, or to compare similarity of two trajectories. 

In summary, this project provides a systematic study on the issue of anonymizing trajectory data, from both fundamental challenges and limits to practical algorithms. The new insights from these discoveries are expected to help reduce the privacy and security concerns in an increasingly connected world. Eight papers have been published in reputable referred conferences with three more under submission. Two Ph.D students have received partial support from this project; one of which has graduated successfully.
